parts.body:
Lee should carry out a one-tailed  $` \QED  `
	test because he is interested to test whether the mean number of birds has *reduced*

Let $`\mu` denote the population mean number of birds visiting the feeder in 20 minutes each morning

$`H_0: \mu = 17.3`
\
$`H_1: \mu < 17.3` $` \QED  `

``` =html
Unbiased estimate of population mean=x=∑xn=51232=16∎
``` ``` =tex \begin{align*} & \text{Unbiased estimate of population mean} \\ &= \overline{x} \\ &= \frac{\sum x}{n} \\ &= \frac{512}{32} \\ &= 16 \; \QED \end{align*} ``` ``` =html
Unbiased estimate of population variance=s2=1n−1(∑x2−(∑x)2n)=132−1(8702−(512)232)=51031∎
``` ``` =tex \begin{align*} & \text{Unbiased estimate of population variance} \\ &= s^2 \\ &= \frac{1}{n - 1}\left( \sum x^2 - \frac{\left( \sum x \right)^2}{n} \right) \\ &= \frac{1}{32 - 1}\left( 8702 - \frac{\left( 512 \right)^2}{32} \right) \\ &= \frac{510}{31} \; \QED \end{align*} ``` Under $`H_0,` $$` \displaystyle Z = \frac{\overline{X}-17.3}{\sqrt{\frac{\frac{510}{31}^2}{32}}} \sim \mathrm{N}(0,1) ` approximately by the Central Limit Theorem since $`{n=32}` is large By GC, $$` p\text{-value} = 0.034911 ` Since $`H_0` is rejected, ``` =html
p-value≤α%0.034911≤α100α≥3.4911
``` ``` =tex \begin{align*} p\text{-value} &\leq \alpha \% \\ 0.034911 &\leq \frac{\alpha }{100} \\ \alpha &\geq 3.4911 \end{align*} ``` Since $`\alpha` is an integer, $$` \text{Minimum integer } \alpha = 4 \; \QED `

There is sufficient evidence at the $`\alpha \%`
level of significance to conclude that the mean number of birds visiting the new bird feeder while he eats his breakfast has reduced $` \QED  `

It is insufficient as the distribution of the number of birds visiting his feeder
is not known to be normal. Hence, for Lee to carry out his hypothesis test, he needs to use
Central Limit Theorem to justify that the mean number of birds visiting his feeder is normally
distributed approximately. $`{n= 10 <30}`
so this sample size is not sufficient $` \QED  `

Lee should carry out a one-tailed test
because he is interested to test whether the mean number of birds has *reduced*.

There is sufficient evidence at the $`\alpha \%`
level of significance to conclude that the mean number of birds visiting the new bird feeder while he eats his breakfast has reduced.

It is insufficient as the distribution of the number of birds visiting his feeder
is not known to be normal. Hence, for Lee to carry out his hypothesis test, he needs to use
Central Limit Theorem to justify that the mean number of birds visiting his feeder is normally
distributed approximately. $`{n= 10 <30}`
so this sample size is not sufficient.
